greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: A Fibbinary system represents a number as a sum of distinct Fibonacci numbers (instead of distinct powers of two). Using representations without adjacent zeros, a(n) = the highest bit-position which changes going from n-1 to n.
comment: A003754(n), when written in binary, is the representation of n.
Often one uses Fibbinary representations without adjacent ones (the Zeckendorf expansion).
reference: Jay Kappraff, Beyond Measure: A Guided Tour Through Nature, Myth and Number, World Scientific, 2002, page 460.
link: Reinhard Zumkeller, Table of n, a(n) for n = 1..10000
formula: a(n) = a(k)+1 if n = ceiling(phi*k) where phi is the golden ratio; otherwise a(n) = 1. - _Tom Edgar_, Aug 25 2015
example: 27 is represented 110111, 28 is 111010; the fourth position changes, so a(28)=4.
program: a083368_list = concat $ h $ drop 2 a000071_list where
xref: A035612 is the analogous sequence for Zeckendorf representations.
A001511 is the analogous sequence for power-of-two representations.
results.author: _Gary W. Adamson_, Jun 04 2003
